0.text: Holofernes and Nathaniel discuss Don Armado, with whom Nathaniel has been conversing. They mock his inferior intellect, criticizing his pronunciation and saying that they abhor 'such rackers of orthography' . Armado, Moth, and Costard enter; Armado tells the learned men that the King has asked him to prepare 'some delightful ostentation, or show, or pageant, or antick or firework'  to entertain the Princess and her party. He asks Holofernes and Nathaniel for their help in planning this entertainment, and Holofernes suggests that they present a show of the Nine Worthies. The men discuss who will play the roles of the Worthies, with Holofernes saying that he will play three of the roles himself. They then go off to plan their show.

2.text: Holofernes and Nathaniel discussed Don Armado, a man whom Nathaniel had previously conversed with. They mocked his lack of intelligence, criticized his pronunciation and said they hated 'people like that with grammar'. Armado, Moth, and Costard entered; Armado told the scholars that the King had requested him to prepare 'the greatest show, or a show, or a show, or a show, or a show, or a fire show' to entertain the princess and her guests. He asked Holofernes and Nathaniel for help in planning the show, and Holofernes suggested that they would perform a show about nine worthy men. The men discussed who would play the worthy men, with Holofernes saying he would play three roles himself. They then went out to plan the show.

The young men discussed who would play the dignitaries, with Holofernes saying he would play three roles for himself. They then stepped out to plan the show.

He asked Holofernes and Nathaniel for help in planning the show, and Holofernes suggested they would perform a show about the nine great gods. 0.text: Jim and the Harling children feel the happiest and most content that spring just playing in the garden. They do not yet know that the summer will change everything. In the beginning of summer, some Italians come into town and set up a dancing pavilion in a vacant lot. They begin giving dancing lessons to children, and people start to gather and congregate around the lot. Now there is something for people to do and somewhere for them to socialize. Dancing becomes a city-wide craze, and every Saturday night there is a late-night dance. Jim goes all the time, as do many girls and boys from the country. At this point, Antonia, Lena, and Tiny become known as 'the hired girls' and are always at the dances too.

2.text: Jim and the Harlings family felt the happiest and most content when they only played in the garden in the spring. They still didn't know that summer would change everything. When summer began, some Italians came to the town and set up a dance troupe on an empty lot. They started teaching dance lessons to the children, and the people began to focus and gather around the lot. Now there was something for everyone to do and a place to connect. Dance became a city-wide phenomenon, and every Saturday night, there was a late-night dance. Jim went every time, as did many girls and boys from the countryside. At this time, Antonia, Lena, and Tiny became the 'waitresses' and always participated in the dances.

4.text: Jim and the Harlings family felt the happiest and most content when they only played in the garden in the spring. They still didn't know that the summer would change everything. When summer began, some Italians arrived in the town and established a dance group on a vacant lot. They started teaching dance classes for children, and the locals began to gather and gather around the lot. Now, there's something for everyone to do and a place to connect. Dance became a city phenomenon, and every Saturday night, there was a late-night dance party. Jim went every time, as did many girls and boys from the countryside. At that time, Antonia, Lena, and Tiny became 'waitresses' and always participated in the dance parties.

0.text: Elizabeth reads through Darcy's letter with a mixture of emotions. When she first reads Darcy's explanation of his conduct with Bingley and Jane, she dismisses his explanation of his concern about Jane's indifference as false, and believes he acted solely because of her family. However, when she begins reading his explanation of the dealings with Wickham, she begins to read more clearly. She soon begins to realize that she had not known anything of Wickham before the night when he told her of he and Darcy, and she wonders why she didn't realize his impropriety at speaking of such things to a stranger. As she continues to reread and think, she realizes that she had been 'blind, partial, prejudiced, absurd,' and that she believes Darcy's version of what happened. She then rereads the section about Jane and Bingley, and sees that she cannot deny the justice of his description of Jane's seeming indifference after all. After two hours of wandering in the park she returns home to be told that both Fitzwilliam and Darcy had come to say their good-byes

2.text: Elizabeth read through Darcy's letter with a mix of emotions. When she first read his explanation for his behavior towards Bingley and Jane, she refused to accept his explanation for his concern over Jane's indifference as insincere, and believed he was acting out of concern for her family. However, as she began to read his explanation for his actions with Wickham, she started to read it more clearly. She quickly began to realize that she knew nothing about Wickham before the night he spoke to her about him and Darcy, and wondered why she hadn't noticed his inappropriateness when he spoke about such things to a stranger. As she continued to read and think about it, she realized that she had been 'blind, biased, prejudiced, and foolish', and believed Darcy's version of events to be true. Then, she read through the part about Jane and Bingley again, and saw that she couldn't deny the fairness of his explanation for Jane's indifference. After a two-hour walk in the park, she returned home and found that both Fitzwilliam and Darcy had come to bid her farewell.

Then she read again about Jane and Bingley, and saw that she could not overlook the fairness of the reasons for Bingley's indifference to Jane. After a two-hour walk in the park, she returned home and found that both Fitzwilliam and Darcy had arrived to bid her farewell.

40.text: Elizabeth read through Darcy's letter with a mix of emotions. When reading about the reasons behind his actions regarding Bingley and Jane, she initially refused to accept the reasons for his interest in Jane, viewing them as insincere and believing he acted out of concern for her family. However, as she began reading about the reasons behind his actions regarding Wickham, she started reading them more clearly. She quickly began to realize that she knew very little about Wickham before he spoke about him and Darcy, and wondered why she had never noticed the inconsistency in his words when talking to strangers. 0.text: Cunegonde tells her story to Candide: Bulgar soldiers attack and kill her family and rape her. While Cunegonde fights off her attacker, a captain comes in and, enraged at the officer's disrespect, kills him. He then takes Cunegonde as a prisoner of war. The captain keeps Cunegonde as his servant for three months and then sells her to a Jewish businessman. The businessman shares her services with the same Inquisitor who ordered the execution of Pangloss and flogging of Candide. Cunegonde wards off the sexual advances of both men. Cunegonde attends the post-earthquake execution and recognizes Candide. Cunegonde's story ends. Back in the present, Candide and Cunegonde eat dinner together and hang out until one of her owners, the businessman Don Issachar, comes to get her.

2.text: Cunegonde recounts to Candide her life story: Bulgarian soldiers attacked and killed her family, and sexually assaulted her. While Cunegonde fought against her attackers, a captain arrived and, enraged by the officer's lack of respect, killed him. The captain then took Cunegonde captive. The captain kept Cunegonde as his servant for three months and then sold her to a Jewish slave trader. The slave trader shared her services with the Inquisitor, who ordered the execution of Pangloss and beat Candide. Cunegonde rejected both men. Cunegonde attended the execution ceremony following the earthquake disaster and recognized Candide. Cunegonde's story ends. Returning to the present, Candide and Cunegonde have dinner together and stay until one of her owners, the slave trader Don Issachar, arrives to take her away.

25.text: Cunegonde recounts her story to Candide: The Bulgarian forces attacked and slaughtered her family, treating her with cruelty and lust. When Cunegonde defended herself against the attackers, a fireman intervened and killed another fireman for his wrongdoing. The fireman then kidnapped Cunegonde. The fireman kept Cunegonde as a maid for three months before selling her to a Jewish slave trader. The slave trader shared her services with the Inquisitor, who had ordered the execution of Pangloss and had beaten Candide. Cunegonde rejected both men. Cunegonde attended the trial following the earthquake disaster and acknowledged Candide. Cunegonde's story has come to an end. Now, Candide and Cunegonde are living together and eating with each other until one of her masters, the Jewish slave trader Don Issachar, arrives to take her away.

30.text: Cunegonde recounts her story to Candide: The Bulgarian forces attacked and killed her family, treating her with cruelty and greed. When Cunegonde defended herself against the attackers, a fireman intervened and killed another fireman for his wrongdoing. The fireman then kidnapped Cunegonde. The fireman held Cunegonde as a servant for three months before selling her to a Jewish slave trader. The slave trader shared her services with the Inquisitor, who ordered the execution of Pangloss and punished Candide with the whip. Cunegonde rejected both men. Cunegonde participated in the trial following the earthquake disaster and recognized Candide. Cunegonde's story has come to an end. Now, Candide and Cunegonde are living together and sharing meals until one of her former owners, the Jewish slave trader Don Issachar, comes to take her away.

40.text: Cunegonde recounted her story to Candide: The Bulgarian forces brutally attacked and killed Cunegonde's family. When Cunegonde defended herself against her attackers, a fire brigade intervened and, through negligence, killed another member of the fire brigade. The fire brigade then kidnapped Cunegonde. The fire brigade kept Cunegonde as a maid for three months before selling her to a Jewish slave trader. The slave trader shared her services with the Inquisitor, who demanded that Pangloss be executed and Candide be punished with a beating. Cunegonde refused both men. Cunegonde testified at a trial after an earthquake devastated the area and identified Candide. Cunegonde's story is now over. Now, Candide and Cunegonde live together and share meals until one of her former masters, the Jewish slave trader Don Issachar, comes to take her away.

0.text: Jane and Rochester have a quiet wedding three days after that. Diana and Mary are happy for her and say they will come to visit. St. John did not reply to the letter Jane sent to him regarding the wedding; however, he has since maintained a correspondence with her. Jane goes to see Adele and changes her school for a better and closer one. Jane then tells the reader that it has been ten years now that she has been married as she sits to write about her life. She and Rochester are always together, and after two years, he had regained sight in one of his eyes, enough to see his first-born son. Diana and Mary are both married and come to visit Jane, and she visits them. St. John went to India and is still there. He remained unmarried, and Jane relates that he feels that he will soon die and join God

2.text: Jane and Rochester organized a quiet three-day wedding. Diana and Mary were overjoyed for her and said they would come visit. St. John did not respond to Jane's letter to him about the wedding; however, he has maintained contact with her since then. Jane visited Adele and changed her school to a better and closer one. Jane then told the reader that it had been ten years since she got married and she sat down to write about her life. She and Rochester have always been together, and after two years, he regained his sight in one of his eyes, enough to see his eldest son. Diana and Mary both got married and visited Jane, and she also visited them. St. John went to India and stayed there. He is still single, and Jane said he felt he would soon die and join God.
